title: How to Clean a Chinchilla Cage

steps.headline: Gather materials.
steps.description: Have a litter scoop, broom, dustpan, and some moistened paper towels handy to clean any messes in or around the chinchilla cage. Daily maintenance of your chinchilla's cage takes approximately five to ten minutes.

steps.headline: Put your chinchilla in a safe place if you like.
steps.description: Since your daily maintenance won't take very long and doesn't require you to remove much from the cage, you can either clean with your chinchilla in the cage or put it in a safe space. If you want to put your chinchilla in a different space, consider putting it in a room like the bathroom where you can close the door. You might want to put some food pellets in the room to keep your chinchilla busy and make it feel safe.

steps.headline: Refill the food dish.
steps.description: It's important to refill the food dish so that your chinchilla always has fresh food that will help keep it healthy. Remove any crumbs or other material, such as feces, before you refill the food dish. If there is urine or feces in the food dish, it's important to remove the dish and clean it thoroughly either in hot, soapy water or your dishwasher. Allow it to dry thoroughly so bacteria can't grow.

steps.headline: Refill the water bottle.
steps.description: It's important that your chinchilla have a clean and working water bottle so that he won't get sick from being dehydrated. Remove any material that might be floating in the water. After you've refilled the bottle with clean water, test to make sure it's flowing properly.

steps.headline: Scoop material from the litter pan.
steps.description: Remove any feces or other material such as loose fur that might be in your chinchilla's littler pan. This will help keep them happy and healthy as well as prevent unpleasant odor.

steps.headline: Remove and replace hay or shavings if necessary.
steps.description: Your chinchilla may spray or defecate outside the litter pan, and it's a good idea to remove any dirty hay or shavings. This will keep your chinchilla happy and healthy, and will also prevent odor.

steps.headline: Spot clean as necessary.
steps.description: After you've completed the other cleaning tasks, spot clean if needed. If your chinchilla has sprayed the walls of the cage, wipe them down with a paper towel and a mild disinfectant. Remove any food pellets or hay that may be outside of the cage. If any material is outside of the cage, clean it up either with a broom or a vacuum.

steps.headline: Gather materials.
steps.description: If you do daily maintenance of your chinchilla cage, weekly cleaning shouldn't require much additional time. Have a broom, dustpan, and some moistened paper towels handy to clean up any messes. Weekly cleaning of your chinchilla's cage takes approximately fifteen to twenty minutes.

steps.headline: Put your chinchilla in a safe place if you like.
steps.description: Since your weekly maintenance won't take very long and doesn't require you to remove much from the cage, you can either clean with your chinchilla in the cage or put it in a safe space. If you want to put your chinchilla in a different space, consider putting it in a room like the bathroom where you can close the door. You might want to put some food pellets in the room to keep your chinchilla busy and make it feel safe.

steps.headline: Wash and refill the food dish.
steps.description: It's important to completely wash the food dish once a week so that your chinchilla won't get sick from old food, mold, or any other bacteria that may be present. Throw away remaining food and wash the dish either in hot, soapy water or in your dishwasher. Allow it to dry thoroughly so bacteria doesn't grow.

steps.headline: Sterilize and refill the water bottle.
steps.description: Sterilizing your chinchilla's water bottle is essential to kill any bacteria that might be present. This helps keep him healthy- and  hydrated. You can either wash the bottle in hot, soapy water or your dishwasher. You can also boil it in a separate pan. Refill the bottle with clean water, and then test to make sure it's flowing properly.

steps.headline: Empty and refill litter pan.
steps.description: Completely empty and refill the litter pan once a week to promote the health and happiness of your chinchilla. This will also help control odor.

steps.headline: Remove and replace hay or shavings.
steps.description: Your chinchilla may spray or defecate outside the litter pan, and it's important to remove any dirty hay or shavings. This will keep your chinchilla happy and healthy, and will also prevent odor.

steps.headline: Spot clean as necessary.
steps.description: After you've completed the other cleaning tasks, spot clean the cage and area around it if needed. If your chinchilla has sprayed the walls of the cage, wipe them down with a paper towel and a mild disinfectant. Remove any loose fur that is in the cage. Sweep away any food pellets or hay that may be outside of the cage with a vacuum. This will also help inhibit the growth of bacteria.

steps.headline: Gather materials.
steps.description: Every month, clean your chinchilla cage completely. Have a broom, dustpan, vacuum, paper towels, a sponge, and disinfectant ready to use. Monthly or bi-monthly cleaning of your chinchilla's cage takes approximately thirty minutes to an hour. If you don't want to use a chemical disinfectant, a one part to one part mixture of vinegar and water is an excellent cleaner for the cage.

steps.headline: Put your chinchilla in a safe place.
steps.description: Before you clean the cage, it's a good idea to take out your chinchilla so that you can clean the space more quickly and effectively. To make your chinchilla more comfortable in their temporary space, scatter some food pellets on the floor.

steps.headline: Empty the entire cage.
steps.description: You're going to clean the cage inside and out, from the walls to the litter pan and food dish and even toys. Removing everything before you start will help you more effectively clean. Throw away any food, water, hay or shavings, and the litter. Putting new material in will contribute to the health and happiness of your chinchilla. Remove any shelves that need replacing.

steps.headline: Clean and disinfect the cage walls.
steps.description: Using either the disinfectant or a vinegar mixture, thoroughly clean and dry the inside and outside walls of the cage. Make sure to allow the cage to dry thoroughly before you replace any dishes, toys, and the litter pan. This will help inhibit the growth of any bacteria or fungus.

steps.headline: Wash and refill litter pan.
steps.description: Washing and refilling the litter pan promotes the health and happiness of your chinchilla. Wash the litter pan with some disinfectant and water. Make sure to let it dry thoroughly before you refill the litter. Wash the litter pan with some disinfectant and water if you like. Make sure to let it dry thoroughly before you refill the litter.

steps.headline: Replace hay or shavings.
steps.description: It's important for your chinchilla to have fresh, clean hay or shavings once a month. This will keep your chinchilla happy and healthy, and will also prevent odor and bacterial growth.

steps.headline: Disinfect and replace toys.
steps.description: Clean toys that are not broken promote the health of your chinchilla. Replace any defective toys or those you can't wash so they don't harm the chinchilla. You can use the same methods to disinfect your chinchilla's toys as you did the food dish: either a one part to one part mixture of vinegar and water, or in hot soapy, water.

steps.headline: Vacuum the area around the cage.
steps.description: This step will help promote the cleanliness of the cage and remove any lingering parts that may contain bacteria.

steps.headline: Rearrange the cage's setup.
steps.description: When you're ready to place your chinchilla's equipment back in the cage, rearrange the setup from what it was like before. Chinchillas like to explore new settings and rearranging the cage's setup will keep them happy and active.

steps.headline: Put your chinchilla back in the cage.
steps.description: Give him a treat for behaving while you cleaned his cage!
